tit.e: Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho (The Nijo River Beach Lampoon)

sen.j: 二条河原の落書（にじょうがわらのらくしょ）とは、室町幕府問注所執事の町野氏に伝わる『建武年間記(建武記)』に収録されている文である。
sen.e: The Nijo river beach lampoon was a writing collected in "Kenmu Nenkan-ki, a record of the Kenmu era (Kenmu-ki)," which was handed down in the Machino clan, the head of Monchujo (Board of Inquiry) in Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 執事→政所・問注所の長官[スーパー大辞林3.0]
sen.e: Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho are writings collected in Kenmu Nenkan-ki, a record of the Kenmu era which was handed down in the Machino clan, which was the head of Monchujo (Board of Inquiry) in Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: Took title out of quotation marks and incorperated it into the sentence proper, to read a bit more naturally. Added "which was" before "the head of" for the same reason.
sen.e: Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho are writings collected in "Kenmu Nenkan-ki," a record of the Kenmu era which was handed down in the Machino clan, which was the head of Monchujo (Board of Inquiry) in Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 88節に渡り、建武の新政当時の混乱する政治・社会を批判、風刺した七五調の文書。
sen.e: It consists of 88 stanzas, and was written in seven-and-five-syllable meter, criticizing and satirizing politics and society in the chaotic days of the Kenmu Restoration.

sen.j: 専門家の間でも最高傑作と評価される落書の一つである。
sen.e: Experts in history consider it to be one of the best lampoons.

sen.j: 建武政権の政庁である二条富小路近くの二条河原（鴨川 (淀川水系)流域のうち、現在の京都市中京区二条大橋付近）に掲げられたとされる落書（政治や社会などを批判した文）で、写本として現代にも伝わる。
sen.e: It has been transmitted in a hand-copied book up to today and is said to have been put up at the Nijo river beach near Nijo Tomikoji Street (near the present day Nijo-Ohashi bridge, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City among the Kamogawa river basin (Yodogawa river system)), where the Kenmu regime's office was.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hand written copies have been passed down through the years up until today, and it is said to have been displayed at the Nijo river beach near Nijo Tomikoji Street in the Kamogawa river basin (Yodogawa river system) (near the present day Nijo-Ohashi bridge, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City) where the Kenmu regime's office was.
sen.cmt: Changed "It has been transmitted in a hand-copied book up to today" to a more natural sounding "Hand written copies have been passed down through the years up until today". Changed "put up" to "displayed" to make the meaning a bit clearer, and changed "among" the river basin to "in" and put that with Tomikoji Street to make their connection clearer.
sen.e: Hand written copies (criticizing and satirizing politics and society) have been passed down through the years up until today, and it is said to have been displayed at the Nijo river beach near Nijo Tomikoji Street in the Kamogawa river basin (Yodogawa river system) (near the present day Nijo-Ohashi Bridge, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City) where the Kenmu regime's office was.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府滅亡後に後醍醐天皇により開始された建武の新政が行われるなか、1334年（建武 (日本)元年）8月に掲げられた。
sen.e: The lampoon was hung out in August, 1334, when the Kenmu Restoration was inaugurated by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The lampoon was displayed on August, 1334, when the Kenmu Restoration was inaugurated by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: "hung out" to "displayed" and "on August" to "in August".
sen.e: The lampoon was displayed on August, 1334, when the Kenmu Restoration was inaugurated by Emperor Godaigo after the fall of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 編者は不詳、建武政権に不満を持つ京都の僧か貴族、京童であるとも。
sen.e: The editors are unknown, but there are rumors that nobles, Kyoto's young people, or monks who were dissatisfied with the Kenmu regime did it.

sen.j: 本文を見ると一種の詩をかたどった文書であり、漢詩や和歌に精通している人物が書いたことは間違いないと思われる。
sen.e: Taking a look at the text, you can see that it was written in a kind of verse, so it must have been written by someone who was familiar with Chinese poetry and waka poems.
